texts.shortText: Large, fat, oval clam with smooth, glossy-white shell often tinged with yellow to brown around growing margin. Swollen around hinge area and often with fine concentric growth lines visible. Young specimens may be marked with pale-brown radiating lines. When live, the ends of the siphons can be seen to be fused. Internally, the hinges of all Mactra species bear a distinctive socket- shaped ligamental pit, from which the common name ‘trough shells’ is derived.

Global: Around Africa, from Senegal in the west to Tanzania in the east.

Local/Regional: Found all around southern African coastline.

Burrows in fine muddy sediments from low water to about 38 m depth and can attain high population densities in suitable sites. Once very abundant in Langebaan Lagoon, but now scarce there. Often washed up in considerable numbers after storms, but can speedily rebury when exposed. Sought after for human consumption.

Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon. In Mactra the siphons are lined internally with branched, interlocking tentacles to keep large particles out.
Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species have not been investigated.

Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to their large size and smooth, oval shells. Juveniles may be confused with the streaked sand-clam Tivela compressa, as the two species occur in the same sites and often wash up together. The shells of T. compressa are, however, densely marked with concentric brown bands, in addition to the radiating streaks found in juvenile M. glabrata. A second species of Mactra, M. auquisulcata is found along the east coast, but does not extend into the Western Cape.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 152).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 178).

Signorelli, JH (2021). The Family Mactridae Lamarck, 1809 (Bivalvia: Cardiida) in South African Waters. Malacologia, 63(2), 195-223.
